data.title: The empresses strike back: China’s royal wives revealed
data.meta_description: The Forbidden City looms like a monument to mystery in the world’s imagination. What secrets lay beyond its encircling ramparts? How was life lived within those high red walls? data.text:
The Forbidden City looms like a monument to mystery in the world’s imagination. What secrets lay beyond its encircling ramparts? How was life lived within those high red walls? For more than half a millennium, serving as the seat of power for first the Ming, then the Qing dynasties, the palace in Beijing jealously guarded its imperial privacy. It was only in 1925, several years after the abdication of the last emperor, that it was transformed into a public museum and the extraordinary details of a domain in which everything was dictated by ritual, protocol and rank were gradually unveiled.

Since then we have learnt more and more of the culture of that sprawling complex of temples and courtyards, pagodas and gardens (it covers more
